lab.name: Boyle's Law
lab.background: In the 1700's a number of people investigated gas behavior in the laboratory. Robert Boyle investigated the relationship between the volume of a dry ideal gas and its pressure. Since there are four variables that can be altered in a gas sample, in order to investigate how one variable will affect another, all other variables must be held constant or fixed. Boyle fixed the amount of gas and its temperature during his investigation. He found that when he manipulated the pressure that the volume responded in the opposite direction. For example, when Boyle increased the pressure on a gas sample the volume would decrease. Mathematically, P is proportional to (1/V) if the gas is behaving as an ideal gas. A practical mathematical expression of Boyle's findings is: PV = constant In this experiment, you will vary the volume of a sample of gas and measure the change in pressure to study this relationship. In the real lab, reducing the volume available to a gas, would initially increase both the pressure and temperature, and then only once the temperature cooled back down to its initial value could the pressure be measured. However, in this simulated lab, the temperature remains constant at room temperature and the pressure values can be read immediately.
lab.assignment: Assignment 1 Procedure #1 Question #1 : 1. According to Boyle's Law, pressure is inversely proportional to volume; so, prepare a graph of the data for propane with [1/volume] (units=1/mL) on the X-axis and pressure (kPa) on the Y-axis. Draw a straight line through the data points. Does your experimental data verify Boyle's Law? Explain. 2. What pressure would the gas sample have at a volume of 75 mL? At 300 mL? 3. List two sources of possible error that could influence your results. Procedure #2 Question #1 : 1. According to Boyle's Law, pressure is inversely proportional to volume; so, prepare a graph of the data for butane with [1/ volume] (units = 1/mL) on the X-axis and pressure (kPa) on the Y-axis. Draw a straight line through the data points. Does your experimental data verify Boyle's Law? Explain. 2. What pressure would the gas sample have at a volume of 75 mL? At 300 mL? 3. How do the results for butane compare with those for propane? Does each gas obey Boyle's law? Use the data contained on the graph to justify your answer.
lab.procedure:
Butane and Propane are combustible materials that can explode if ignited. In this virtual investigation, assume that all experimental work occurs within a fume hood in which there are no open flames.

1. Take a 150-mL Erlenmeyer flask from the Glassware shelf and place it on the workbench. 2. Double click on the flask to bring up the properties for the flask, and check the checkbox for "Lid Closed" to close the flask. 3. Take a pressure gauge from the Tools shelf and attach it to the flask. Double click the pressure gauge and set the units to "kPa". 4. Fill the flask with 1 atm (101.325 kPa) of propane gas (C3H8), making sure to check the "Flush Air" option in the Amount dialog box. This ensures that the flask contains only propane gas. 5. Open the Data window to view the volume of the gas sample. 6. Record the pressure and volume of the gas sample. 7.Add 20 mL H2O to the flask. (It is added through the flask's cover, as though injected by a syringe). 8. Record the new pressure and volume of the gas sample. The gas volume is equal to the total volume of the flask minus the volume of the water. 9. Continue to make 20-mL "injections" of water up to a total of 100 mL, recording the pressure and volume after each addition. Procedure #2 Repeat the steps of Procedure 1 for butane gas (C4H10).
